repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
One feature I think the Lua API is missing is convenience functions for working with window layouts. This is the first of my ideas, mostly just an alternative to `vim.fn.winlayout`. 

I'd also like to implement `nvim_tabpage_set_layout` as a counterpart to this, which would allow for easily configurable layouts to be created in user configs, but that will likely be a larger task and probably needs discussion on what the API would look like. My idea is that it would take the same structure that `tabpage_get_layout` returns, but instead of leaves containing window handles, they would contain buffer handles which would be used to populate the layout windows.

Todo: tests - need to figure out how to assert window layouts.

comment_data.body: Now it's no longer a Dictionary.
Ahh okay, thanks! Still getting a handle on the type system here.
What about the nil case? Should I just return an empty array?
yes, empty array should be fine (when is that possible ? ðŸ˜† )
So to be clear, vim_to_object performs a copy  so the memory held by whatever it's converting from is no longer needed?
Yes. There is a similar example in lines 317-319 in src/nvim/context.c.
Thanks, I'll check that out. I appreciate the help!

Can use either a string to open a buffer, or a number to use an already-opened buffer. Setting buflisted manually is a bit hacky, but I don't know of a better way to open a buffer from Lua and get its bufnr. Could use input on that.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -976,4 +976,41 @@ do
   end
 end
 
+---@param tabpage tabpage
+---@param layout table
+function vim._set_layout(tabpage, layout)
+  local function set_layout(node)
+    local ty = node[1]
+    if ty == 'leaf' then
+      local buf = node[2]
+      if type(buf) == 'string' then

comment_regular_data.body:
Thanks for the PR, window layout is definitely something we want to expose more deeply: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/3933

> mostly just an alternative to `vim.fn.winlayout`.

New APIs need a stronger motivation than that. New C APIs are justified when (1) exposing C internals that aren't exposed or (2) adding new features that can't be added from Lua.

`set_layout` sounds much more compelling. But can it take the same structure that is returned by `winlayout()`, or why not?

If we end up adding new API for this, perhaps `winlayout()` can be implemented with it. Having multiple different implementations of similar-but-different things is a burden.

> New APIs need a stronger motivation than that. New C APIs are justified when (1) exposing C internals that aren't exposed or (2) adding new features that can't be added from Lua.

That's fair! My main motivation for the different structure to `fn.winlayout` is ease of use from Lua, as many window-related plugins implement functions that convert the output of `fn.winlayout` to a format similar to the one created here. The only other thing I can think of is consistency with `set_layout` in the future and keeping with the pattern of `nvim_[scope]_[get/set]_[property], but that may not be so important. 

> `set_layout` sounds much more compelling. But can it take the same structure that is returned by `winlayout()`, or why not?

`set_layout` definitely could take the same format as `fn.winlayout` if that would be preferred. Now that I'm thinking about it, much of the reason a plugin would implement a transformation on the layout tree would be negated by `set_layout` anyways since transformations would be automatically applied and one would just need to swap window / buffer handles in the tree to move things around.

I'd also be interested in implementing functions exposing more granular control over window layout, such as accessing and manipulating individual frames within a tabpage's layout, but that definitely needs discussion as I don't think there's anything related exposed by the API at the moment.

> If we end up adding new API for this, perhaps `winlayout()` can be implemented with it. Having multiple different implementations of similar-but-different things is a burden.

Not quite sure what you mean by this. Reimplementing / replacing winlayout()?
The implementation of `winlayout()` is just 37 lines (blank lines excluded).

> The implementation of `winlayout()` is just 37 lines (blank lines excluded).

It is very efficient :) I think that returning the same structure as `winlayout()` would make my implementation a bit smaller, but I agree that the current implementation is good. 

This probably isn't needed right now, but if `set_layout` existed it would be convenient and predictable to have a corresponding `get` function.

> The implementation of `winlayout()` is just 37 lines (blank lines excluded).

Well, `get_framelayout` exists for it only. And the `frame_get_layout` added in this PR is a re-implementation of that. So that definitely adds tech debt. 

And having 2 different user-facing structures that represent "window layout" is pretty ugly.

If we truly have a better way of representing window layout, let's deprecate and plan to remove `winlayout()`. Otherwise let's stick with the same structure.

> And having 2 different user-facing structures that represent "window layout" is pretty ugly.
> 
> If we truly have a better way of representing window layout, let's deprecate and plan to remove `winlayout()`. Otherwise let's stick with the same structure.

That makes sense. Should I rework this to keep the same structure as `winlayout()`, keep this as a draft and then start on `set_layout`? Or would it be better for me to scrap this and work on set_layout separately with the assumption that `fn.winlayout()` will continue to be the only way of fetching layout?

> Should I rework this to keep the same structure as `winlayout()`, keep this as a draft and then start on `set_layout`?

That's what I would suggest, until proven otherwise. get_layout in that case is just a passthrough and it should eliminate `frame_get_layout`, right?

> That's what I would suggest, until proven otherwise. 

Sounds good!

> get_layout in that case is just a passthrough and it should eliminate `frame_get_layout`, right?

Most likely - the implementation for `winlayout()` is currently static and defined in `nvim/eval/` not `nvim/api/`, would it be acceptable to make that nonstatic and include `nvim/eval/window.h` in `nvim/api/tabpage.c`?
Thanks for the quick reviews! I'll make those changes.

Regarding `set_layout`:

Would it be beneficial for the layout tree to handle window views, so you'd pass a buffer handle and optional window view properties (`fn.winsaveview`) with each leaf? Or is that too much complexity and better handled separately after the layout is set?

> Regarding `set_layout`:
> 
> Would it be beneficial for the layout tree to handle window views, so you'd pass a buffer handle and optional window view properties (`fn.winsaveview`) with each leaf? Or is that too much complexity and better handled separately after the layout is set?

That is probably a necessary feature, but could be a followup PR? It seems useful for "restore window layout" to be a single operation so that Nvim can better avoid janky redraw.

Note also this limitation of `:help winrestcmd()`:

> Only works properly when no windows are opened or closed and the current window and tab page is unchanged.

`set_layout` should of course not have that limitation.

> That is probably a necessary feature, but could be a followup PR? It seems useful for "restore window layout" to be a single operation so that Nvim can better avoid janky redraw.

Exactly my thoughts. Definitely would make sense to do that in a separate PR, will make initial implementation simpler.

I'm a bit busy today but will likely get started on this tonight!

Currently working on this - struggling a bit with creating windows. I've been able to use `win_split_ins` to create splits, but I've spent a fair amount of time with rg and LSP poking around `src/nvim/windows.c` and trying different things and still haven't been able to directly modify the layout. Any pointers on where I should look? Thanks :)

> and still haven't been able to directly modify the layout. Any pointers on where I should look?

I'd start by copying the idea from winrestcmd(): https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/996dd36c77321ea91758b5996d152a2f37af99dd/src/nvim/eval/window.c#L770

of course, it's just print a bunch of `:resize` and `:vert resize` commands, but could use their C equivalents instead: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/996dd36c77321ea91758b5996d152a2f37af99dd/src/nvim/ex_docmd.c#L5175

It's also fine to just start with exactly what winrestcmd() produces, and execute it as vimscript using `do_cmdline_cmd`: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/996dd36c77321ea91758b5996d152a2f37af99dd/src/nvim/insexpand.c#L1244

Then after you have test coverage, can revisit the implementation if needed.

I wouldn't spend a lot of time building up the C logic. Instead I would delegate as much as possible to Lua, and call the Lua function from C https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/996dd36c77321ea91758b5996d152a2f37af99dd/src/nvim/api/vim.c#L1878

you could put your Lua code in `runtime/lua/vim/shared.lua` for now.

Sounds good, that makes sense! I'll try to keep as much as possible on the Lua side. I was mainly trying to insert windows / frames into the layout manually to ensure best possible performance when doing a bunch of window operations simultaneously, but creating the splits via lua / vimscript makes more sense for now. Plus I definitely don't know the codebase well enough yet to understand the side affects of making those changes in C.

> I was mainly trying to insert windows / frames into the layout manually to ensure best possible performance

Can turn various knobs before/after `NLUA_EXEC_STATIC` , such as `RedrawingDisabled`: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/996dd36c77321ea91758b5996d152a2f37af99dd/src/nvim/drawscreen.c#L304-L310

I'm not sure we have any way of "double buffering" a window layout, so the main cost we have control over (AFAIK) is whether we immediately render stuff as we evaluate each split command.

For sure, delaying redraw probably will do the trick. The only other way I can think of would be using a separate tabpage then swapping their top-level frames after all layout setup is done, but I don't think there's a way to create unlisted tabpages and that would probably not be worth the complexity anyways.

> other way I can think of would be using a separate tabpage then swapping their top-level frames after all layout setup is done, but I don't think there's a way to create unlisted tabpages

There is precedent for that general idea, `aucmd_prepbuf` https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/996dd36c77321ea91758b5996d152a2f37af99dd/src/nvim/autocmd.c#L1237 but it's more for correctness, not performance.

> > other way I can think of would be using a separate tabpage then swapping their top-level frames after all layout setup is done, but I don't think there's a way to create unlisted tabpages
> 
> There is precedent for that general idea, `aucmd_prepbuf`
> 
> https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/996dd36c77321ea91758b5996d152a2f37af99dd/src/nvim/autocmd.c#L1237
> 

Could be interesting, maybe could be done in a followup PR if the initial implementation has flicker or janky redraw.  

> but it's more for correctness, not performance.

Yeah, I have no idea what the actual performance implications would be anyways, mainly just guessing based on "no FFI faster than FFI".
Relatively simple implementation but it works :)

This is working, but there are a few things that I think could be better, but were maybe too complicated for the initial implementation. These can/should addressed in this PR or followups:
- Searching the previous layout for windows that can be reused instead of closing all of them (update by difference)
- Setting window view and size properties
- Determining which window should be focused after the layout is setup
- Better way of opening new buffers

Edit: Not quite sure how to address the doc lints. Is the issue just formatting?

Edit 2: A [gist](https://gist.github.com/willothy/0f4888bb9c5f5330f0899843f6207402) with usage example

title: feat(api): nvim_tabpage_[get/set]_layout
